<math display="inline">A4 = 440 \text{Hz}</math>, then using the canonical mapping of <math display="inline">C \to 0, C\sharp \to 1, \ldots, B \to 11</math>, let's call that mapping <math display="inline">n</math>, so that <math display="inline">n\left(E\right)=4</math> then the function which maps scientific notation to the frequency is given by<math display="block">\mathcal{F}\left( \stackrel{Y}{X} \right) \stackrel{\mathtt{D}}{ = } 440\text{Hz}  \cdot 2 ^{Y - 4}  \cdot 2^{\frac{X}{12}} </math>We can see that <math>\mathcal{F} (\stackrel{4}{11}) = 440\text{Hz} \cdot 2^{0} \cdot 2^{\frac{11}{12}}</math>
